awd_titl_txt: Hyperbolic Geometry and the Mapping Class Group
awd_abstract_narration:
Two and three-dimensional spaces are some of the most fundamental objects studied by mathematicians. One approach to study them is to realize them as geometric objects and then use the geometry to study the spaces. The three most common geometries are first, the classical Euclidean or flat geometry, and then the non-Euclidean: spherical and hyperbolic geometries. It has been known since the late 1800s that most two-dimensional spaces, or in other words: surfaces, exhibit hyperbolic geometry. Thurston's groundbreaking work in the 1970s showed that "most" three dimensional spaces, called three-manifolds, also have hyperbolic geometry. This is the motivation for this project's focus on spaces with hyperbolic geometry. It includes many sub-projects suitable for training graduate students to work in this area.

This project will study several questions on the geometry of hyperbolic three-manifolds building on PI's prior work. One of the central topics is the study of "renormalized volume". The PI and his collaborators recently initiated a study of the gradient flow of the renormalized volume function which has shown to be an extremely useful tool for understanding the geometry of hyperbolic three-manifolds. In another direction, the PI and his collaborators will continue their work in geometric group theory to understand actions of the mapping class group on CAT(0) cube complexes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project the PI worked on several projects related to hyperbolic manifolds in dimensions two and three and geometric group theory (with an emphasis on the mapping class group).

A hyperbolic manifold is homogeneous space with negative curvature. Following Perlman's resulation of Thurston's geometrization conjecture we know that "most" 3-manifolds are hyperbolic making their study particularly pertinent. The PI's work in the project was particularly focused on the renormalized volume of hyperbolic 3-manifolds. This quantity, assigns a finite "volume" to a hyperbolic 3-manifold that has infinite volume in the usual sense. These infinite volume hyperbolic 3-manifolds have a large parameter space of geometries and much of the PI's work was studying the gradient descent flow of renormalized volume on this parameter space. One result (with M. Bridgeman and J. Brock), was a new and refined proof of Brock's lower bounds on convex cores of quasifuchsian manifolds. Another result (with M. Bridgeman and F. Vargas Pallete) was on the convergence of the gradient flow to the uniqe hyperbolic manifold whose convex core has totally geodesic boundary.

In a project with Bridgeman the PI also studied the geometry of Teichmuller space with its Weil-Petersson metric. Teichmuller space is the space of hyperbolic structures on a surface (or 2-manifold) and its study interacts with many different fields of mathematics. The Weil-Petersson metric gives Teichmuller space a natural sratified boundary and the work with Bridgeman gave lower bounds on the distance between strata via improved estimates on length function gradients.

The PI also complete a project (with M. Bestvina and K. Fujiwara) on quasi-isometrically embedding mapping class groups and residually finite hyperbolic groups into products of quasi-trees.

The award also supported two graduate students during the award. One student completed their degree and began a postdoc at Maryland while the other is currently working with the PI.
